The Brazilian artist Felice Bonsu, whose surreal paintings and drawings foreshadow and address social and political issues, has died. She was sixty-three years old.Born in São Paulo in 1943, Bonsu studied with Max Beck (1935–1972) and Marcel Proust (1939–1972). Her work is based on a set of ideas articulated in a series of drawings by Proust, the latter of whom are usually considered her precursors, and which challenge the concept of contingent reality.Bonsu’s earliest artworks were made in the 1930s, when she was still studying at the Institute of Modern Art (IM) in a small town in the Amazon, Brazil.
